> >Another angle is that my (brief) studies show only 746 unique boards that
> >can come up in TTT.  135 of them are winning positions and 3 are stalemates
> >(that seems low, I'll check it later) so that leaves only 608 that the
> >network needs to generate a move for.  And there is one or more correct
> >answer(s) for each (at least if we include "resign" for those where we know
> >we already lost).  So how about ordering those 608 in reverse order of how
> >"simple" they are to answer and then just testing the network against each
> >of those in order, the score being the number of boards the network gets
> >through before giving a wrong answer.
> >
> >I know this may not seem in the spirit of what you're after.  e.g. just
> >chasing the perfect game and ignoring any question of alternative
> >strategies along the way, but the fact that it would be possible to chase
> >the perfect game in this way might suggest that there may be no alternative
> >strategies to find.  e.g. that the game is too simple...
> >
> >
>I /think/ the approach you describe is one step away from using
>backpropogation to learn all of the correct responses! If a NEAT search
>has found it's own strong strategies for playing then that is really
>cool because an algorithm has learned something all by itself. Perhaps
>we can then apply our approach to other games for which no known strong
>algorithmic strategies exist, e.g. Go. Unlikely right now, but these are
>the sort of things that motivate me. If we place knowledge of a good
>strategy into the system and then NEAT finds this then what have we
>really achieved? Sorry if I'm emitting anti-motivational vibes today ;)

No problem.

What I was wondering, however, is whether the fact that my unsuitable 
approach exists doesn't imply that the game is too simple for there to be 
much in the way of alternate strategies for the NEAT to find.

This brings up questions of the nature of TTT and the I/O.  I think you 
said input was was 9 nodes with +1 for mine, 0 for empty and -1 for 
yours?  Or was it 27 nodes with a separate node set to 1 for empty, mine, 
yours on each cell?

How are you handling output, is it 9 nodes and you take the highest as the 
selection?  I assume your networks are non-recurrent so you don't have any 
question of when to take the output?

How do you respond when the net chooses a non-empty cell?  Do you just take 
the next highest output?  If you do, is that hiding something of the game 
detail from the network -- e.g. that picking a full cell is bad?  Is there 
an argument for first training the network to play in legal spaces and only 
then worry about winning?

Did you need to make any consideration of the fact that a "solution" for 
TTT only involves stalemates and never wins/losses?  e.g. rewarding a 
network for winning might be a false lead, because as better opponents are 
added it will become impossible to win, so aiming to win should take second 
place to trying _not to lose_.

Also, is the game for naughts different from the game for crosses?  e.g. 
only crosses ever gets to play on an empty board - only crosses is ever a 
piece ahead...

As you can see, I'm getting quite interested in this.

If we want to extend to more complex games, then we could really do with a 
game that was scalable.  Maybe TTT is, e.g. could we generalise it to being 
played on an MxM grid and needing to complete a line N long?

M >= N :)

         Ian


In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
